ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I feel like I have a grasp now on what grant organizations are looking for in their applications, and how to structure these better. I also have more broad knowledge about practical research methods and how to think about them in cultural anthropology!

- research ethics in anthropology - methods in sociocultural anthropology (e.g., kinship analyses, various approaches to participant observation, (semi)structured interviews, focus groups) - grantwriting skills & structure of the NSF
- Designing ethnographic research - Writing grant proposal
- streamlining my research question and representation

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: - organization - content --> extremely practical! - opportunities for feedback Weaknesses: - time management (was scheduled for 2hrs but often took 2.5) - wish more class materials were available / assignments could be submitted electronically

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Very useful for anyone embarking on the grant process, which is most social scientists. Especially useful for cultural anthropologists but applicable to other disciplines as well.
Yes! This course was extremely helpful for considering Ana practicing methods in sociocultural anthropology and for writing and receiving feedback on a full NSF DDIG proposal
